qas.question: How many bilateral agreements did Bern and Brussels sign to further liberalise trade ties?
What was included in the first series of bilateral agreements pertaining to people?
When was a second series of 9 bilateral agreements signed?
What has since happened to the second series of bilateral agreements?
What were the original bilateral agreements meant to minimize the negative consequences of?

answers.text: Switzerland's isolation from the rest of Europe

context: The government has established an Integration Office under the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Economic Affairs. To minimise the negative consequences of <a4_0>Switzerland's isolation from the rest of Europe<a4_0/>, Bern and Brussels signed <a0_0>seven<a0_0/> bilateral agreements to further liberalise trade ties. These agreements were signed in 1999 and took effect in 2001. This first series of bilateral agreements included the <a1_0>free movement of persons<a1_0/>. A second series covering nine areas was signed in <a2_0>2004<a2_0/> and <a3_0>has since been ratified<a3_0/>, which includes the Schengen Treaty and the Dublin Convention besides others. They continue to discuss further areas for cooperation.
